form.longName: PhenX PX530102 - Cognitive Flexibility Dimensional Change Card Sort You
form.preferredDefinition: The Dimensional Change Card Sort (DCCS) Standard Version is an interviewer-administered task that measures the flexible use of rules to govern behavior as a means of providing an index of executive function in young children. In this task, the assessor asks the participant to sort bivalent test cards according to one dimension (e.g., color) and then the other (e.g., shape). The Dimensional Change Card Sort task is a freely available, simplified version of the Wisconsin Card Sort test. For more information about the Wisconsin Card Sort test, please refer to the www.cognitiveatlas.org/task/id/tsk_4a57abb949f21|Cognitive Atlas Interpretation.

headerInstruction.text: Summary of the Dimensional Change Card Sort (DCCS) Standard Version :The Dimensional Change Card Sort (DCCS) Standard Version makes use of two different styles of bivalent cards, displaying for example a red boat and blue rabbit. The protocol ..TRUNCATED

module.longName: Cognitive Flexibility (Dimensional Change Card Sort) - Young Children
module.preferredDefinition: Cognitive Flexibility (Dimensional Change Card Sort) - Young Children

question.questionText: Dimension used for preswitch phase of sorting. (dimension_preswitch_phase)
Number of preswitch cards correctly sorted: __________ (number_preswitch_cards_correctly_sorted)
Number of postswitch cards correctly sorted: __________ (number_postswitch_cards_correctly_sorted)

Scoring: Typically, postswitch performance is only evaluated for participants who correctly sort five or more of the six preswitch cards. Participants are scored as having passed or failed the task as scores are usually bimodally distributed between being all correct or all incorrect on postswitch trials. Participants who correctly sort five or more of the six postswitch cards are considered to have passed the task. Most healthy threeyearold children fail the postswitch phase of the standard version of the DCCS, exhibiting inflexibility, while most healthy four and fiveyearold children pass as their flexibility increases. (scoring_530102)

protocol.longName: Cognitive Flexibility (Dimensional Change Card Sort) - Young Children
protocol.preferredDefinition: The Dimensional Change Card Sort (DCCS) Standard Version is an interviewer-administered task that measures the flexible use of rules to govern behavior as a means of providing an index of executive function in young children. In this task, the assessor asks the participant to sort bivalent test cards according to one dimension (e.g., color) and then the other (e.g., shape). The Dimensional Change Card Sort task is a freely available, simplified version of the Wisconsin Card Sort test. For more information about the Wisconsin Card Sort test, please refer to the www.cognitiveatlas.org/task/id/tsk_4a57abb949f21|Cognitive Atlas Interpretation.

form.longName: PhenX PX530201 - Decision Making Iowa Gambling Task Child
form.preferredDefinition: The child version of the Iowa Gambling Test™, developed by Garon and Moore (2004), is an interviewer-administered task originally given to children aged 3-6. The participant selects one card at a time from four decks. Participants are instructed that each card selected will result in winning candy, with some cards also taking candy away. The goal of the task is to accumulate as much candy as possible. Several summary scores can be calculated, including total candy won and difference between advantageous and disadvantageous selections. For more information about the Iowa Gambling Test, please refer to www.cognitiveatlas.org/task/id/tsk_4a57abb949ae5|Cognitive Atlas Interpretation.

question.questionText: Scoring: Several summary scores can be derived, including total amount of candy won, total number of cards selected from each deck, and the total scores from the awareness portion of the test (see Garon and Moore, 2004, for more details). The Iowa Gambling Test™ is a trademark of PAR, Inc (scoring_530201)

protocol.preferredDefinition: The child version of the Iowa Gambling Test, developed by Garon and Moore (2004), is an interviewer-administered task originally given to children aged 3-6. The participant selects one card at a time from four decks. Participants are instructed that each card selected will result in winning candy, with some cards also taking candy away. The goal of the task is to accumulate as much candy as possible. Several summary scores can be calculated, including total candy won and difference between advantageous and disadvantageous selections. For more information about the Iowa Gambling Test, please refer to www.cognitiveatlas.org/task/id/tsk_4a57abb949ae5|Cognitive Atlas Interpretation.

form.longName: PhenX PX530301 - Delayed Reward Discounting Monetary Choice Questionnaire
form.preferredDefinition: The Monetary-Choice Questionnaire is a 27-item self-administered questionnaire. For each item, the participant chooses between a smaller, immediate monetary reward and a larger, delayed monetary reward. The protocol is scored by calculating where the respondent's answers place him/her amid reference discounting curves, where placement amid steeper curves indicates higher levels of impulsivity. For more information about the Monetary-Choice Questionnaire, please refer to www.cognitiveatlas.org/task/id/tsk_4a57abb949e98|Cognitive Atlas Interpretation.

headerInstruction.text: For each of the next 27 choices, please indicate which reward you would prefer: the smaller reward today, or the larger reward in the specified number of days.

question.questionText: Scoring: A participant's discounting curve may be calculated according to the following function: V = A/(1+kD); V is the present value of the delayed reward A at delay D, and k is the rate of discounting. k typically falls between 0.0 and 0.5, with smaller values indicating a lack of discounting and preference for delayed rewards and higher values indicating strong discounting and a preference for immediate rewards. Thus higher values of k are indicative of high levels of impulsivity. There are two ways of scoring the Monetary-Choice Questionnaire. The first involves hand scoring to get an estimate of k following the guidelines given in Kirby (2000). The second involves fitting a logistic regression function to individual responses following procedures described in Wileyto et al. (2004). Estimating Discounting Rate. The following lists the calculated k values (the degree of discounting) at indifference for each question (i.e., when the subjective value of the immediate and delayed rewards are equivalent). *Questions 13, 1 and 9: k at indifference=.00016 *Questions 20, 6 and 17: k at indifference=.00040 *Questions 26, 24 and 12: k at indifference=.0010 *Questions 22, 16 and 15: k at indifference=.0025 *Questions 3, 10 and 2: k at indifference=.0060 *Questions 18, 21 and 25: k at indifference=.016 *Questions 5, 14 and 23: k at indifference=.041 *Questions 7, 8 and 19: k at indifference=.10 *Questions 11, 27 and 4: k at indifference=.25 An estimate of the respondent's discounting rate can be calculated as the geometric mean (to avoid underweighting) of the k at indifference between the two questions that reflect when the respondent changes between choosing the delayed reward versus the immediate reward. In cases where the respondent's change between preferring the delayed versus the immediate reward is not consistent, the two questions that are most proportional to their responses are chosen. If the participant always..TRUNCATED(scoring_530301)

protocol.preferredDefinition: The Monetary-Choice Questionnaire is a 27-item self-administered questionnaire. For each item, the participant chooses between a smaller, immediate monetary reward and a larger, delayed monetary reward. The protocol is scored by calculating where the respondent's answers place him/her amid reference discounting curves, where placement amid steeper curves indicates higher levels of impulsivity. For more information about the Monetary-Choice Questionnaire, please refer to www.cognitiveatlas.org/task/id/tsk_4a57abb949e98|Cognitive Atlas Interpretation.

form.longName: PhenX PX540301 - Family Risk And Protective Factors
form.preferredDefinition: The protocol includes 38 self-administered questions from the Communities That Care Youth Survey. This protocol includes seven subscales: Poor Family Management (8 items on a 4-point scale), Family Conflict (3 items on a 4-point scale), Parental Attitudes Favorable to Antisocial Behavior (3 items on a 4-point scale), Attachment (4 items on a 4-point scale ), Opportunities for Prosocial Involvement (3 items on a 4-point scale), Rewards for Prosocial Involvement (4 items on a 4-point scale), Parental Attitudes Favorable toward Drug Use (3 items), and Family History of Antisocial Behavior (including Drug Use) (10 items on a 5-point scale). Attachment, Opportunities for Prosocial Involvement, and Rewards for Prosocial Involvement are protective (or promotive) factors; the remaining subscales are risk factors.

headerInstruction.text: This is not a test, so there are no right or wrong answers we would like you to work quickly, so that you can finish. Some of the questions have the following format: Please check the answer that best describes how you feel about that sentenc..TRUNCATED

question.questionText: How wrong do your parents feel it would be for you to: drink beer, wine or hard liquor (for example, vodka, whiskey, or gin) regularly (at least once or twice a month)? (how_wrong_parents_feel_drink)
How wrong do your parents feel it would be for you to: smoke cigarettes? (how_wrong_parents_feel_cigarettes)
How wrong do your parents feel it would be for you to: smoke marijuana? (how_wrong_parents_feel_marijuana)
How wrong do your parents feel it would be for you to: steal something worth more than $5? (how_wrong_parents_feel_steal)

How wrong do your parents feel it would be for you to: draw graffiti, or write things or draw pictures on buildings or other property (without the owner's permission)? (how_wrong_parents_feel_graffit)
How wrong do your parents feel it would be for you to: pick a fight with someone? (how_wrong_parents_feel_fight)
Have any of your brothers or sisters ever: drunk beer, wine or hard liquor (for example, vodka, whiskey, or gin)? (brothers_sisters_ever_drunk)

validValue.meaningText: I don't have any brothers or sisters
validValue.description: I don't have any brothers or sisters

question.questionText: Have any of your brothers or sisters ever: smoked marijuana? (brothers_sisters_ever_smoked_marijuana)

validValue.meaningText: I don't have any brothers or sisters
validValue.description: I don't have any brothers or sisters

question.questionText: The rules in my family are clear. (family_rules_are_clear)
Has anyone in your family ever had a severe alcohol or drug problem? (family_member_alcohol_drug_problem)
People in my family often insult or yell at each other. (family_often_insult_yell)
When I am not at home, one of my parents knows where I am and who I am with. (parents_know_where_i_am)
We argue about the same things in my family over and over. (family_argue_same_things)
If you drank some beer or wine or hard liquor (for example, vodka, whiskey, or gin) without your parents' permission, would you be caught by your parents? (beer_caught_by_parents)
My family has clear rules about alcohol and drug use. (family_has_rules_alcohol_drug)
If you carried a handgun without your parents' permission, would you be caught by your parents? (carried_handgun_caught_by_parents)
If you skipped school, would you be caught by your parents? (skipped_school_caught_by_parents)
My parents notice when I am doing a good job and let me know about it. (parents_notice_good_job)
Do you feel very close to your mother? (close_to_your_mother)
Do you share your thoughts and feelings with your mother? (share_thoughts_feelings_with_mother)
My parents ask me what I think before most family decisions affecting me are made. (q15_540301)
How often do your parents tell you they're proud of you for something you've done? (frequency_parents_proud)
Do you share your thoughts and feelings with your father? (share_thoughts_feelings_with_father)
Do you enjoy spending time with your mother? (enjoy_spending_time_with_mother)
Do you enjoy spending time with your father? (enjoy_spending_time_with_father)
If I had a personal problem, I could ask my mom or dad for help. (ask_mom_dad_for_help)
Do you feel very close to your father? (feel_very_close_to_father)
My parents give me lots of chances to do fun things with them. (chances_for_fun_with_parents)
My parents ask if I've gotten my homework done. (parents_ask_homework_done)
People in my family have serious arguments. (family_serious_arguments)
Would your parents know if you did not come home on time? (parents_know_not_home_time)
About how many adults (over 21) have you known personally who in the past year have used marijuana, crack, cocaine, or other drugs? (adults_who_used_drugs)
About how many adults (over 21) have you known personally who in the past year have sold or dealt drugs? (adults_who_sold_dealt_drugs)

About how many adults (over 21) have you known personally who in the past year have done other things that could get them in trouble with the police like stealing, selling stolen goods, mugging or assaulting others, etc. (adults_who_done_other_things)
About how many adults (over 21) have you known personally who in the past year have gotten drunk or high? (adults_gotten_drunk_or_high)

protocol.preferredDefinition: The protocol includes 38 self-administered questions from the Communities That Care Youth Survey. This protocol includes seven subscales: Poor Family Management (8 items on a 4-point scale), Family Conflict (3 items on a 4-point scale), Parental Attitudes Favorable to Antisocial Behavior (3 items on a 4-point scale), Attachment (4 items on a 4-point scale ), Opportunities for Prosocial Involvement (3 items on a 4-point scale), Rewards for Prosocial Involvement (4 items on a 4-point scale), Parental Attitudes Favorable toward Drug Use (3 items), and Family History of Antisocial Behavior (including Drug Use) (10 items on a 5-point scale). Attachment, Opportunities for Prosocial Involvement, and Rewards for Prosocial Involvement are protective (or promotive) factors; the remaining subscales are risk factors.

form.longName: PhenX PX540501 - School Risk And Protective Factors
form.preferredDefinition: The protocol includes nine self-administered questions from two School Protective Factors subscales/constructs (Opportunities for Prosocial Involvement and Rewards for Prosocial Involvement) from the Communities That Care (CTC) Youth Survey. The CTC Survey does not include a scale of School Drug Environment (a risk factor), which is supplemented here with a scale from the Seattle Social Development Project (SSDP) longitudinal study.

headerInstruction.text: This is not a test, so there are no right or wrong answers we would like you to work quickly, so that you can finish. Mark (the BIG) YES! if you think the statement is definitely true for you. Mark (the little) yes if you think the statement i..TRUNCATED

question.questionText: Putting them all together, what were your grades like last year? (9) (grades_last_year)
During the LAST FOUR WEEKS, how many whole days of school have you missed because you skipped or "cut"? (10b) (days_of_school_skipped)
In my school, students have lots of chances to help decide things like class activities and rules. (12) (students_help_decide_activities_rules)
Teachers ask me to work on special classroom projects. (13) (special_classroom_projects)
My teacher(s) notices when I am doing a good job and lets me know about it. (14) (teacher_notices_good_job)
There are lots of chances for students in my school to get involved in sports, clubs, or other school activities outside of class. (15) (chances_for_activities_outside_class)
There are lots of chances for students in my school to talk with a teacher onetoone. (16) (talk_with_a_teacher)
I feel safe at my school. (17) (feel_safe_at_school)
The school lets my parents know when I have done something well. (18) (school_lets_my_parents_know)
My teachers praise me when I work hard in school. (19) (my_teachers_praise_me)
Are your school grades better than the grades of most students in your class? (20) (grades_better_than_most_students)
There are lots of chances to be part of class discussions or activities. (21) (part_of_class_discussions_activities)
How often do you feel that the schoolwork you are assigned is meaningful and important? (22) (meaningful_and_important_schoolwork)
How interesting are most of your courses to you? (23) (how_interesting_courses)
How important do you think the things you are learning in school are going to be for your later life? (24) (how_important_learning_later_life)
Now, thinking back over the past year in school, how often did you... enjoy being in school? (25a) (how_often_enjoy_beingin_school)
Now, thinking back over the past year in school, how often did you... hate being in school? (25b) (how_often_hate_beingin_school)
Now, thinking back over the past year in school, how often did you....try to do your best work in school? (25c) (how_often_try_your_best)
For these last questions, think about the school you (currently/last) (attend/attended). (info_540501)
What grade (are/were) you in? (what_grade)
Most people in my school think it's OK for people my age to drink alcohol. (ok_drink_alcohol)
What percentage of the students in your grade at your school have drunk any alcohol this year? Would you say... (percentage_students_drunk_alcohol_yearly)
What percentage of the students in your grade at your school drank alcohol at least once or twice a month. Would you say... (percentage_students_drank_alcohol_monthly)
Most people in my school think it's OK for people my age to smoke cigarettes. (ok_smoke_cigarettes)
What percentage of the students in your grade at your school have smoked any cigarettes this year? Would you say... (percentage_students_smoked_cigarettes_yearly)
What percentage of the students in your grade at your school smoked cigarettes at least once or twice a month. Would you say.... (percentage_students_smoked_cigarettes_monthly)
Most people in my school think it's OK to use marijuana (pot/grass). (ok_use_marijuana)
What percentage of the students in your grade in your school have smoked any marijuana this year? Would you say.... (percentage_students_smoked_marijuana_yearly)

During the past year, what percentage of the students in your grade in your school have smoked marijuana at least once or twice a month? Would you say.... (percentage_students_smoked_marijuana_monthly)

protocol.preferredDefinition: The protocol includes nine self-administered questions from two School Protective Factors subscales/constructs (Opportunities for Prosocial Involvement and Rewards for Prosocial Involvement) from the Communities That Care (CTC) Youth Survey. The CTC Survey does not include a scale of School Drug Environment (a risk factor), which is supplemented here with a scale from the Seattle Social Development Project (SSDP) longitudinal study.
